newsitem.title: UK: Copper ends firm on LME, spread tightness increase.
newsitem.headline: Copper ends firm on LME, spread tightness increase.

text.p: Copper prices were well supported during Thursday afternoon LME trading by an ever-expanding backwardation, and closed steadier, albeit under the key $2,280 level.
Elsewhere, there was a contracting contango in the aluminium market, which reflected forward borrowing and short dates in April, which lifted prices above the $1,640 level.
The price perforance in the rest of the complex was mixed, although the general undercurrent was steadier on copper's trend.
In copper, the cash/threes backwardation widened out to $290/294 by the end of the kerb, against Wednesday's $250.
The crunch prompt dates are between Jan 29 and the February date, with some of the end-Jan/early-Feb daily rates now around $20, close to the LME's one percent of cash metal daily limit.

Traders said the tightness, which covers around two weeks, reflects a combination of genuine physical shortages, major short positions from a speculative sell-off in autumn 1996, and merchant players taking advantage of the situation.
Meanwhile, three months prices repeatedly stalled at the $2,280 level, finishing the kerb at $2,277 a tonne, up $15 from Wednesday.
"A close above $2,280 would have been mega-bullish on the charts, but I think it is heading that way. The next $50 on copper is likely to be on the upside," one trader said.
If $2,280 is cleared, the psychological target is $2,300, although the key overhead objective will be $2,313 - the late November 1996 high.
Once through here prices will be back to levels last seen in June 1996, when the market was in full retreat as the Sumitomo scandal unfolded.
In aluminium, attention centred on short April dates, notably around April 9. There is also talk that significant tonnages of metal will be drawn out of warehouses in coming weeks, they said.
This pulled in the cash/threes contango to $24/25 by the close from $30 on Wednesday. Three months prices pushed above the $1,640 level to end $12 higher at $1,642 and are now set for further gains.
Zinc continued to erode reistance just above $1,150 and closed the day at $1,151, up $1, but lead was quiet and drifted to close at $712, down $1.
Nickel recovered from yesterday's softness, rallying on some covering to finish at $7,385, up $105. Tin continued to build a base above $6,000, and was $30 higher at $6,050.
The aluminium alloy market was indicated at a slightly steadier $1,535/40 a tonne. --Martin Hayes, London Newsroom 44 171 542 8080
